subject: Re: [junit] Do we need to convince management of the benefits of unit tests?
msgSnippet: ... If I think some code needs to be removed I remove it, if I think some code needs to be added I add it, if I think some code needs to be changed I change
messageBody:
>
> > We make so many descisions we don't ask permission for like "is it ok to
> > remove this dead code?
>
> You don't?! I see it all the time. More specifically, I see people
> acting as though they do /not/ have permission to remove dead code. "If
> it ain't broke, don't fix it" and "Don't touch it; it might break"
>

If I think some code needs to be removed I remove it, if I think some
code needs to be added I add it, if I think some code needs to be
changed I change it. If I feel uncertain I ask someone for more
information/dig for more information before I descide what to do.

Of course it is easier to be certain if there are tests to verify that
stuff works after I'm done. In some systems I just don't know that the
code is dead... having permission to remove it doesn't make me more
certain so I tend to look for information rather than permission. Also
if I get permission to do something it will still be my fault if I'm
wrong since permission is IME granted based on the infomration
presented /only/... tough one... no wonder dead code tends to stay in
systems...

> , can I use a factory here?,
> > can I draw a UML-diagram on the whiteboard?, can I save it in
> > documentation?, can I call a designmeeting?" so why is unit-testing
> > different?
>
> Anything that a project manager in particular might perceive as /extra/
> time is different. That includes refactoring, testing (we have a whole
> department for that), design meetings, and so on. Of course, it depends
> on what activities that project manager participated in himself when he
> wrote code.

Yes, I'm aware of that and talking about things is usually not
preceived as extra time since talking is free and coding costs
money... Writing documents also costs less money then coding right? :)

In my experience people are less interested in /how/ you work as long
as you deliver. Working stuff is in general more apreachiated than
broken stuff (but that is unfortunately not always the case since
fixing broken stuff in the last minute can make you a hero).

TDD is a way of delviering things, so what keeps an individual from
doing it? I seldom see any eyebrows raised when developers write
main(String[] args) methods to test their code and I never saw any of
those developers ask management for permission to do that...

>
> > I think, if you manage to convince your team /first/ then management is as
> > good as convinced when the results start showing.
>
> ...but in the meantime, when the team goes through the chaos period,
> management has plenty of time and opportunity to step and say, "See? I
> told you this stuff was extra effort. Why are you doing this? Stop
> wasting our money."
>

That is true. My idea was basically that by setting a good example it
may rub off on others and that you can evolve gently into TDD without
chaos... That contradicts my experience from reality but I want it to
be true...

> > I think by example is the best way to go, start with your self and influence
> > those around you.
> >
> > /if/ you are convinced about the benefits of unittesting then /not/ doing
> > unittesting would be unprofessional since you choose not to do it.
> > So start doing it and infect the others. Don't have managment inject the
> > virus into an unwilling team by placing demands on testcoverage etc.
> > That will rebound in my experience.
> >
> > So, what do you think? Should we tell the story to our fellow developers
> > instead of management?
>
> I don't understand why you would frame the question as "instead of". Why
> not "in addition to"? I think my manager deserve to know what I'm doing.

Good point, I wanted to shift the image. Maybe I should have said
should we tell the story to the developers /and/ management I still
think that the biggest challenge is convincing developers. If all
developers showed conviction that TDD is the better way to go the
descision would be easy for management. Generally it is not like that
and management is faced with convincing their developers that TDD
rocks /if/ they descide to go that way and implement TDD.

I also think that management has a right to know what I am doing. In
addition to that I am not sure that management is interested in every
detail about how I'm doing it as long as I deliver satisfactory
results. When we set out on crusades to convince management on the
benefits of TDD maybe we are making too big a deal out of it? Is there
anyway we can start out small and evolve to where we want to go?

I was on a company when I was able to convince management to let me
run a TDD-pilot. Since that went well demands on unittests for all
projects followed shortly after. The request from the projects came
backsoon after that on some metrics that would show that the demand
had been met. The reply came after some time that 70% test coverage
was the demand.

Cool! too bad I didn't get that having unit-tests is pretty worthless
if the authors don't know why they are writing them (if only reason
developers are writing them is to reach the magic number of 70%
testcoverage). Some homework remained to be done...

Summary: I don't know whats best. Sure, convince management.don't hide
stuff (that was not what I meant) but /don't forget to get your fellow
developers on the train/. If they are on the train convincing
management is easier. If they are not I don't know if you have a
case...
